repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
This is a minimum viable product to allow paths in `NVIM_APPNAME`. It is enough to fix #23056 but does not yet address the points raised in #24966

The current implementation means a user with multiple configs will end up with a lot of messy directories that may not be clear they relate to neovim (depending on what the appname they used once and then forgot about was).

Allowing the appname to include sub-directories would mean that they can choose to group all these together,
e.g.
```
NVIM_APPNAME="neovim-configs/first-config" nvim
NVIM_APPNAME="neovim-configs/second-config" nvim
```
It would also allow the user to clone someones dotfiles repo and then reach the config without moving it from the repo (this is a key part to how [dotfyle-cli](https://github.com/rorynesbitt/dotfyle-cli) works),
e.g.
```
git clone git@github.com:user/dotfiles ~/.config/user/dotfiles
NVIM_APPNAME="user/dotfiles/.config/nvim" nvim
```

I am looking for feedback about what else would need to be included in this for it to be merged.
I don't know c but I'm willing to do what I can if pointed in the right direction

From the relevant issue:
- [ ] updated stdpath logic in various places
- [ ] update to the docs
- [x] block the inclusion of `../` in the appname

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -616,10 +616,25 @@ describe('stdpath()', function()
 
     -- Check that Nvim rejects invalid APPNAMEs
     -- Call jobstart() and jobwait() in the same RPC request to reduce flakiness.
-    eq(1, exec_lua([[
-      local child = vim.fn.jobstart({ vim.v.progpath }, { env = { NVIM_APPNAME = 'a/b\\c' } })
-      return vim.fn.jobwait({ child }, 3000)[1]
-    ]]))
+    local function runAppnameTest(testAppname, expectedExitCode)

comment_data.body: The for loop is specifically for `..` as although absolute paths can't be used you can do the equivalent by setting appname to `../../../../../effectively/absolute/path`
I'm not sure what you're meaning here, do you want me to set that variable instead of the early return?
i'm saying `path_is_absolute` should be used instead of checking `appname[0] == PATHSEP`

I did not know that was an option, that would have saved such a headache yesterday.
Thanks for the info :smile: updated it

I double checked, the new test will fail if the for loop is taken out, and yes I know that means my test for the for loop fails without the for loop. But I checked in case `path_is_absolute` had a way of looking for `..`

comment_regular_data.body:
The new appname check looks for the equivalent of`/../`, `^../`, or `/..$`     (or `\\`)
This means that if someone for whatever reason has .. in the middle of a valid filename then that will still work, it will only get blocked when it is being used to mean parent directory.

This should mean that `XDG_xx` variables are still correctly made use of, but still allow for subdirectories. In which case are the other two changes still required?

Please always say clearly what problem is being solved, and give an example. 

The first obvious question is, if `NVIM_APPNAME=$HOME/t` then what are `stdpath('config')` and `stdpath('cache')` expected to return? 

> In which case are the other two changes still required?

re "updated stdpath logic in various places": for example, `stdpath('config')` and `stdpath('cache')` are currently assumed (correctly) to be separate directories. But if `NVIM_APPNAME` can be set to an absolute path then that falls apart. Neither Nvim nor plugins can reason about "the cache directory" if it's the same directory as "the config directory". 

### Other notes:

- > The new appname check looks for the equivalent of`/../`, 
    - Instead of checking for ".." literally, can the path be resolved to an unambiguous, absolute path (which is then compared with the umabiguous, absolute form of CWD or its parent)? That should be more robust. Though I don't remember if we have a robust "normalize" function internally, yet.
- If this PR ends up being viable then it would need tests, e.g. the [discussion](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/discussions/24954#discussioncomment-6870419) mentions `tempname()`.

> Please always say clearly what problem is being solved, and give an example.

I've updated the original comment

> The first obvious question is, if `NVIM_APPNAME=$HOME/t` then what are `stdpath('config')` and `stdpath('cache')` expected to return?

This is an interesting question and not something I was planning to support here. The idea behind checking for `..` is that it has to remain a subdirectory of the normal `stdpath('config')` and `stdpath('cache')` etc
I suppose the extension of this logic is to also make sure the appname doesn't start with a path separator, `$HOME/t` would become `/home/user/t` and therefore the initial `/` would throw the error.

> re "updated stdpath logic in various places": for example, `stdpath('config')` and `stdpath('cache')` are currently assumed (correctly) to be separate directories. But if `NVIM_APPNAME` can be set to an absolute path then that falls apart. Neither Nvim nor plugins can reason about "the cache directory" if it's the same directory as "the config directory".

Again, this is not the intention of this pr


>  * Instead of checking for ".." literally, can the path be resolved to an unambiguous, absolute path (which is then compared with the umabiguous, absolute form of CWD or its parent)? That should be more robust. Though I don't remember if we have a robust "normalize" function internally, yet.

It was suggested to me that I make use of realpath to check the actual location of the directory. Although this would mean symlinks to strange places would not work and my personal opinion on that is if the user is symlinking they probably have a reason for it (like gnu stow). So my check deliberately stuck to the idea of "what does the string look like" not "where does the resulting directory rest".
I am of course open to differing opinions from the more wise

> * If this PR ends up being viable then it would need tests, e.g. the [discussion](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/discussions/24954#discussioncomment-6870419) mentions `tempname()`.

I shall make sure to add tests. `tempname()` should be the only thing really effected,,I think

> The first obvious question is, if NVIM_APPNAME=$HOME/t then what are stdpath('config') and stdpath('cache') expected to return?

After some testing I don't think this is actually a problem (although I would still block it because it could cause confusion).

When I set the appname to this I don't get anything put in `/home/rory/t` I get `/home/rory/.local/state/home/rory/t` etc.
I am inferring from this that an absolute path is never actually possible and since linux treats `//` like `/` it will "just work". But I would not expect it to just work on windows, in fact I don't even know if the check I added would work on windows

I'm not entirely sure if that's the best way to do the tests, I based them on the one that was already there.
~~Also the old test suggests that `\\` should be read as a `PATHSEP` but I'm assuming that would only be windows? in which case maybe I should seperate the tests with `if is_os('win') then` and test for both `/` and `\\` options~~ I have discovered `alter_slashes()`, the tests make more sense now

Hey @justinmk , I think I've addressed all your issues, would appreciate another look when you get the time.

Things I'm anticipating, but I'm not sure about:
- Move the updated test that makes sure incorrect appnames are ignored to a separate test, rather than the one it was in before when it was a simpler check? If so where would you want it?
- rebase the commits to be shorter, or would you squash them all together? Maybe something like:
```
fix(tempname): substitute PATHSEP for '_' in directory name
feat(NVIM_APPNAME): allow relative paths
test(options/defaults_spec): add tests for NVIM_APPNAME as a path
```
- as per the ci checks, would you want something about this in news?
- `local waitTime = (expectedExitCode == -1) and 100 or 3000` This works, but do we actually care about wasting time in tests?

> as per the ci checks, would you want something about this in news?

yes. also `:help NVIM_APPNAME` will need to say "must be a name or relative path"

> local waitTime = (expectedExitCode == -1) and 100 or 3000 This works, but do we actually care about wasting time in tests?

test time matters very much, we'll need to find a better approach

> yes. also `:help NVIM_APPNAME` will need to say "must be a name or relative path"

Added both these things

> test time matters very much, we'll need to find a better approach

The idea behind that line of code was that if we expect nvim to error with that appname set then it would happen very quickly anyway, and 3000 was the timeout used on the previous check incase it didn't. However, if we expect nvim to accept the appname then we will always be waiting for the timeout to occur, so I made it much shorter. 
I fear to say "it works on my machine" but an alternative option is to keep the timeout always at 100. My tests still get the correct results with that set
I done the rebase to appease the commit linter. Hope that's chill :smile:

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: Let NVIM_APPNAME be a path
